Man.speaker: Man
Man.text: You never know ahead of time what something's really going to be like.

Man.speaker: Man
Man.text: Sometimes it seems like life is as delicate as a dandelion.

Man.speaker: Man
Man.text: One little puff from any direction, and it is blown to bits.

Man.speaker: Man
Man.text: She loved you, you know. You were the best friend she's ever had.

Skully.speaker: Skully
Skully.text: I'll let you in on a little secret. Lean in closer.

choices: How are you this fine morning?
What do you want from me?

You.speaker: Me
You.text: Well, mind your own business then.

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text: How did this work again? Which one do I press...

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: Dad! Hello? Can you hear me?

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text: Johnny, my boy! Can you hear me alright?

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: Yeah, dad. I can hear you. Can you hear me?

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text: Yes! Yes, it's good to hear you again, Johnny. How are you doing?

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: Good, dad. I'm doing good.

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text:
Look! I got springrolls! I made 'em this morning, so they're damn ugly. The
cooking ladies on the internet make everything look so easy.

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: It looks really good, dad. You're getting a lot better at it.

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text:
I'm gonna get you to try it once you can get home. I'll keep practicing. Maybe
one of these days, they'll taste like your mom's.

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: Yeah, that'd be great.

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text: What have you got, Johnny?

choices: As you can see, I just got the usual frozen microwave dinner.
You know, I just got the usual frozen microwave dinner.

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text: That actually doesn't look half bad! You must be pretty busy, eh, Johnny?

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: Yeah, work really tires me out.

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text:
Oh, Johnny. I keep tellin' you that those things aren't good for you. Full of
plastic and chemicals. You gotta watch your health, or you'll regret it when you
get to my age.

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: I know, dad. Work just really tires me out.

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text: Well, I'm starving. Let's eat.

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text: Munch munch munch...

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: Munch munch munch...

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: So, what else did you do today? Munch munch munch...

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text:
Munch munch munch... Not a lot. I took a nap and watched some TV. There's never
anything interesting on anymore. Not things I like, anyway.

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text:
That sounds nice. I think I'll have to do overtime again this weekend. Not
looking forward to that. Munch munch munch...

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text:
They're working you half to death! Munch munch munch... You gotta find a place
that treats you better, Johnny. I'm telling you, I never worked overtime like you
do when I was your age.

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: I know, dad. I'm looking. Munch munch munch...

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text: Cheers! Glug glug glug...

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: Cheers! glug glug glug...

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text:
It was good seeing you again, Johnny. Make sure you get home whenever you can.
Come home soon.

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: I know, dad. It'll take some time, but I'm trying.

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text: I know.

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: Goodnight, dad. I'll see again, same time next week.

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text: Goodnight.

Son.speaker: Son
Son.text: (Stands and walks away, tossing his plastic container into the trash.)

Son.speaker: Dad
Son.text:
(Looks out the window, then back at the black screen. Stands and shuffles to the
sink to clean the dishes. He drops a towel and reluctantly picks it up, tired,
then continues on his way.)
